title: Bitcoin and Ethereum: Two titans battle for NFT supremacy - Forkast News
summary: Bitcoin and Ethereum are vying for dominance in the non-fungible token (NFT) space, with two major events happening over the weekend: Veecon Indianapolis 2023 and the BTC Miami/Ordinals Conference 2023. The NFT community is split between the "status quo" ETH-based community and a newly emerged BTC-based community. At Forkast Labs, we work on CryptoSlam.io to include all new and relevant chains, and I met industry celebrities like Richerd Chan from Manifold.xyz. I asked him if he was developing for Bitcoin, and he replied that he wasn't and wasn't sure if the BTC community was supporting Ordinals. The latest rankings on CryptoSlam.io show that $OXBT and $ORDI are in the top 10, indicating the rapid rise of Bitcoin in the NFT scene. title: $51,000 Ethereum (ETH) Now on the Table, According to VanEck – Here’s Their Outlook - The Daily Hodl
summary: VanEck, a global investment manager, predicts that Ethereum (ETH) could reach $51,000 by 2030 if certain conditions are met. The company lays out three possible scenarios: base, bear, and bull cases. In the base case, ETH could reach $11,848.62, while in the bear case, it could fall to $343.29. The bull case projection of $51,006 is based on the assumption that Ethereum becomes the dominant open-source global settlement network. VanEck notes that ETH is evolving into a store-of-value asset, similar to Bitcoin, but with a different approach. However, the firm emphasizes that investors should do their own research and due diligence before making any high-risk investments in cryptocurrencies or digital assets.

title: Arbitrum-based Jimbos Protocol hacked, losing $7.5M in Ether - Cointelegraph
summary: Arbitrum-based Jimbos Protocol hacked, losing $7.5M in Ether. Jimbos Protocol, a liquidity protocol on the Arbitrum system, was hacked, resulting in the loss of 4,000 Ether (ETH) worth $7.5 million. The attack exploited a lack of slippage control on liquidity conversions, allowing attackers to reverse swap orders for their gain. This is the latest in a series of DeFi protocol hacks, highlighting the persistent challenge of safeguarding against potential vulnerabilities and unauthorized access in the crypto industry.

title: What are Ethereum MEV bots? - The Cryptonomist
summary:
Sure, here's a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

Ethereum MEV bots are individuals who use powerful hardware and specialized software to exploit techniques that maximize profit in block validation and publishing on the Ethereum blockchain. These techniques include asset price arbitrage, frontrunning or sandwich attacks, and loan liquidations in DeFi. While MEV bots can generate significant profits, they also create complex issues for the Ethereum community, such as increased gas prices and potential threats to consensus and network integrity. The article concludes that the future of MEV bots on Ethereum is uncertain and may be subject to changes or solutions by Vitalik and the Ethereum foundation.

title: Layer 2 Data Fees Hit All-Time High on Ethereum's Blockchain - The Coin Republic
summary: Layer 2 data fees on the Ethereum blockchain have reached an all-time high, driven by increased usage of off-chain transactions due to their benefits. Optimistic rollups have contributed the most to the high transaction fees, with Arbitrum and Optimism leading the way. Meanwhile, Polygon's zkEVM has seen a significant decrease in Total Value Locked (TVL) compared to its competitors.
